text: Welcome nivo.bubblechart. package brings power Nivoâ€™s circle packing visualizations R, making straightforward create interactive bubble charts data analysis Shiny applications. bubble charts? title: Getting Started with nivo.bubblechart
code: library(shiny) library(nivo.bubblechart)  sample_data <- list(   name = "Tech Companies",   children = list(     list(name = "Apple", value = 2800, color = "#A3AAAE", labelColor = "#000000"),     list(name = "Microsoft", value = 2500, color = "#00A4EF", labelColor = "#ffffff"),     list(name = "Google", value = 1800, color = "#4285F4", labelColor = "#ffffff"),     list(name = "Amazon", value = 1600, color = "#FF9900", labelColor = "#000000"),     list(name = "Meta", value = 900, color = "#0668E1", labelColor = "#ffffff")   ) )  ui <- fluidPage(   titlePanel("Market Cap Visualization"),   sidebarLayout(     sidebarPanel(       h4("Selected Company"),       verbatimTextOutput("selected_company")     ),     mainPanel(       bubblechartOutput("tech_chart", height = "600px")     )   ) )  server <- function(input, output, session) {    output$tech_chart <- renderBubblechart({     bubblechart(       element_id = "tech_bubble",       main_color = "#667eea",       label_color = "#ffffff",       on_hover_title_color = "#FFD700",       activeColor = "#FF6B6B",       borderWidth = 2,       data = sample_data,       height = "600px"     )   })    output$selected_company <- renderPrint({     clicked <- input$tech_bubble_clicked      if (is.null(clicked)) {       cat("Click a bubble to select")     } else if (clicked == "DESELECT_EVENT") {       cat("Deselected")     } else {       cat("Selected:", clicked)     }   }) }  shinyApp(ui, server)

code: bubblechart(   element_id,   main_color,   label_color,   on_hover_title_color,   data = NULL,   width = NULL,   isInteractive = TRUE,   height = "400px",   activeColor = "transparent",   borderWidth = 3 )

title: Create an Interactive Bubble Chart â€” bubblechart
text: element_id Character string specifying Shiny input ID click events. Click events accessible Shiny input$<element_id>_clicked. example, element_id = "my_chart", click events available input$my_chart_clicked. main_color Character string specifying default color bubbles (hex color code, e.g., "#ff5f56" red, "#3498db" blue). color used base color chart border fallback. label_color Character string specifying default label text color (hex color code). Use high-contrast colors better readability (e.g., "#ffffff" white text dark bubbles, "#000000" black text light bubbles). on_hover_title_color Character string specifying label color hovering bubble (hex color code). color applied label text user hovers mouse bubble, providing visual feedback. data nested list representing hierarchical data. Must "name" field root "children" field containing child nodes. child : name: Display name bubble (character) value: Numeric value determining bubble size (must positive) color: Hex color code bubble fill (character, e.g., "#3498db") labelColor: Hex color code label text (character, e.g., "#ffffff") Use prepare_bubble_data convert data frames format. width width widget. Can valid CSS unit (e.g., "100 percent", "400px", "50vw") NULL automatic sizing. NULL recommended responsive layouts. isInteractive Logical. TRUE (default), enables click hover interactions. Set FALSE static charts reports presentations interactivity needed. height height widget. Can valid CSS unit (e.g., "400px", "600px", "50vh") NULL. Default "400px". Adjust based layout needs amount data displayed. activeColor Character string specifying color selected/active bubbles (hex color code). user clicks bubble, changes color. Default "transparent", makes selected bubble see-. borderWidth Numeric value specifying border width bubbles pixels. Default 3. Use larger values (e.g., 5) prominent borders, smaller values (e.g., 1) subtle borders, 0 borders.

title: Create an Interactive Bubble Chart â€” bubblechart
code: if (interactive()) { library(nivo.bubblechart)  # Example 1: Basic bubble chart with manual data sample_data <- list(   name = "root",   children = list(     list(name = "Category A", color = "#ff5f56", labelColor = "#ffffff", value = 100),     list(name = "Category B", color = "#ffbd2e", labelColor = "#ffffff", value = 200),     list(name = "Category C", color = "#27c93f", labelColor = "#ffffff", value = 150)   ) )  bubblechart(   element_id = "my_chart",   main_color = "#ff5f56",   label_color = "#ffffff",   on_hover_title_color = "#000000",   data = sample_data,   height = "500px" )  # Example 2: Using prepare_bubble_data for data frame conversion df <- data.frame(   product = c("Laptop", "Phone", "Tablet"),   sales = c(45000, 38000, 22000),   category_color = c("#3498db", "#e74c3c", "#f39c12"),   text_color = rep("#ffffff", 3) )  chart_data <- prepare_bubble_data(   df,   name_col = "product",   value_col = "sales",   color_col = "category_color",   label_color_col = "text_color" )  bubblechart(   element_id = "sales_chart",   main_color = "#3498db",   label_color = "#ffffff",   on_hover_title_color = "#2c3e50",   data = chart_data,   height = "600px" )  # Example 3: Customized appearance bubblechart(   element_id = "custom_chart",   main_color = "#2c3e50",   label_color = "#ecf0f1",   on_hover_title_color = "#f39c12",   activeColor = "#e74c3c",  # Red when selected   borderWidth = 5,          # Thicker borders   data = sample_data,   isInteractive = TRUE ) }

code: prepare_bubble_data(   df,   name_col = "name",   value_col = "value",   color_col = "color",   label_color_col = "labelColor",   root_name = "root",   default_color = "#ff5f56",   default_label_color = "#ffffff" )

title: Prepare Data Frame for Bubble Chart â€” prepare_bubble_data
text: df data frame containing data. Must least two columns: one names one values. Color columns optional. name_col Character string specifying column name bubble names. text displayed bubble. Default "name". value_col Character string specifying column name bubble values. values determine size bubble - larger values create larger bubbles. Values must positive numbers. Default "value". color_col Character string specifying column name bubble colors, NULL. provided, column contain hex color codes (e.g., "#3498db"). NULL column exist, default_color used. Default "color". label_color_col Character string specifying column name label colors, NULL. provided, column contain hex color codes text labels. NULL column exist, default_label_color used. Default "labelColor". root_name Character string root node name. used internally visualization typically need changed. Default "root". default_color Character string default bubble color (hex code). Used color_col NULL row missing color value. Default "#ff5f56" (warm red). default_label_color Character string default label text color (hex code). Used label_color_col NULL row missing label color. Default "#ffffff" (white). Use "#000000" black text light backgrounds.

code: list(     name = <root_name>,     children = list(       list(name = ..., value = ..., color = ..., labelColor = ...),       list(name = ..., value = ..., color = ..., labelColor = ...),       ...     )   )

title: Prepare Data Frame for Bubble Chart â€” prepare_bubble_data
text: R users work tabular data data frames, bubble charts require hierarchical (nested list) structures. function handles conversion automatically, allowing specify columns contain bubble names, values, colors. function particularly useful : data data frame want visualize bubble chart data comes database query, CSV file, API returns tabular data want apply conditional coloring based data values need dynamically generate chart data Shiny applications data frame color columns, function use default_color default_label_color parameters bubbles. can also mix match - example, providing color column letting function use default label color.

title: Prepare Data Frame for Bubble Chart â€” prepare_bubble_data
code: # Example 1: Basic conversion with all columns present df <- data.frame(   name = c("Apple", "Banana", "Cherry"),   value = c(100, 200, 150),   color = c("#ff5f56", "#ffbd2e", "#27c93f"),   labelColor = c("#ffffff", "#ffffff", "#ffffff") )  bubble_data <- prepare_bubble_data(df) str(bubble_data) #> List of 2 #>  $ name    : chr "root" #>  $ children:List of 3 #>   ..$ :List of 4 #>   .. ..$ name      : chr "Apple" #>   .. ..$ value     : num 100 #>   .. ..$ color     : chr "#ff5f56" #>   .. ..$ labelColor: chr "#ffffff" #>   ..$ :List of 4 #>   .. ..$ name      : chr "Banana" #>   .. ..$ value     : num 200 #>   .. ..$ color     : chr "#ffbd2e" #>   .. ..$ labelColor: chr "#ffffff" #>   ..$ :List of 4 #>   .. ..$ name      : chr "Cherry" #>   .. ..$ value     : num 150 #>   .. ..$ color     : chr "#27c93f" #>   .. ..$ labelColor: chr "#ffffff"  # Example 2: Using custom column names sales_df <- data.frame(   product = c("Laptop", "Phone", "Tablet"),   revenue = c(45000, 38000, 22000),   brand_color = c("#3498db", "#e74c3c", "#f39c12") )  chart_data <- prepare_bubble_data(   sales_df,   name_col = "product",   value_col = "revenue",   color_col = "brand_color",   default_label_color = "#ffffff" )  # Example 3: Using default colors (no color columns) simple_df <- data.frame(   category = c("A", "B", "C", "D"),   amount = c(50, 120, 80, 200) )  bubble_data <- prepare_bubble_data(   simple_df,   name_col = "category",   value_col = "amount",   default_color = "#9b59b6",        # Purple   default_label_color = "#ffffff"   # White )  # Example 4: Conditional coloring based on values data_df <- data.frame(   item = c("Small", "Medium", "Large", "X-Large"),   size = c(50, 150, 300, 500) )  # Add colors based on size data_df$color <- ifelse(data_df$size > 250, "#27ae60",  # Green for large                  ifelse(data_df$size > 100, "#f39c12",  # Orange for medium                         "#e74c3c"))                      # Red for small data_df$labelColor <- "#ffffff"  bubble_data <- prepare_bubble_data(data_df, name_col = "item", value_col = "size")  # Example 5: Use with bubblechart if (interactive()) { library(nivo.bubblechart)  df <- data.frame(   fruit = c("Apples", "Oranges", "Bananas", "Grapes"),   sales = c(450, 280, 320, 150) )  chart_data <- prepare_bubble_data(   df,   name_col = "fruit",   value_col = "sales",   default_color = "#3498db",   default_label_color = "#ffffff" )  bubblechart(   element_id = "fruit_sales",   main_color = "#3498db",   label_color = "#ffffff",   on_hover_title_color = "#2c3e50",   data = chart_data,   height = "500px" ) }
